tips.title: Yeast-Bread Tips
content: When a recipe gives a range for the flour amount, use the minimum as a guide and knead in as much of the remaining flour as you can.
Knead the dough to the stiffness called for in the recipe. Kneading develops the gluten of the flour, which determines the final structure of the bread loaf.

To knead, fold the dough over and push down with the heel of your hand, curving your fingers over the dough. Give the dough a quarter-turn, then fold over and push down again. Continue this fold-push-turn procedure until the dough is smooth and elastic.
Don't raise dough in a hot area because excessive heat will kill the yeast. Too much cold, on the other hand, will stunt the yeast's growth. The optimum temperature for raising dough is 80°F.
For best results, place the bowl of dough in an unheated oven, then set a large pan of hot water under the bowl on the oven's lower rack.
Let dough rise till it's nearly doubled in size. Don't let loaves rise to the top of the pan because the dough needs room to rise as it bakes.
For a soft and shiny crust, brush loaves with margarine or butter after baking. For a glossy, crispy crust, brush before baking with milk, water, or beaten egg.
Test for doneness by tapping the top of the loaf with your finger. A hollow sound means the loaf is properly baked.
If you live at a high altitude, expect yeast doughs to rise faster than at sea level. The higher you live, the faster the doughs will rise.
notes: Dough Stiffness Guide:
Soft dough - too sticky to knead, often used for batter breads
Moderately soft dough - slightly sticky, may be kneaded on a floured surface, used for most sweet breads
Moderately stiff dough - somewhat firm to the touch, kneads easily on a floured surface, used for most unsweet breads
Stiff dough - firm to the touch and easily rolled on a floured surface. French bread is made from this type of dough.

tips.title: Cake Baking Tips
content: Use the exact ingredients listed in a recipe. Substitutions, such as shortening for margarine or butter, will alter the cake's texture and flavor.
Turn your oven on to preheat, then start mixing your cake. Your oven should be preheated (allow 10 to 15 minutes) at about the same time you're done mixing the cake.

Cool layer cakes in their pans on wire racks for 10 minutes (loaf cakes, 15 minutes), then loosen the edges. Place an inverted rack on each cake and turn over; lift off the pan. Place a second rack over the cake and invert again.
Invert angel, sponge, and chiffon cakes in their pans as soon as they are removed from the oven to prevent them from shrinking or falling. Then cool completely.

tips.title: Candy Temperature Stages
content: Testing Candy Mixtures: The easiest way to make sure your candy comes out right is with a candy thermometer. Always begin each candy-making session by checking your thermometer's accuracy. Place the thermometer in boiling water for a few minutes, then read it. If the thermometer registers above or below 212°F, add or subtract the same difference in degrees from the recipe temperature.
For an accurate reading, make sure the bulb of the thermometer is completely covered with liquid, not just foam, and that it doesn't touch the bottom of the pan.

Cold Water Test: If you don't own a candy thermometer, use the following test. Working quickly, drop a few drops of the hot mixture from a spoon into a cup of very cold (but not icy) water. With your fingers, form the drops into a ball. Remove the ball from the water. The firmness of the ball will indicate the temperature of the mixture.
notes: 1. Thread stage (230° to 233°F): When a teaspoon is dipped into the hot mixture, then removed, the candy falls off the spoon in a fine, thin thread.
2. Soft-ball stage (234° to 240°F): When the ball of candy is removed from the cold water, the candy instantly flattens and runs between your fingers.
3. Firm-ball stage (244° to 248°F): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it is firm enough to hold its shape, but quickly flattens at room temperature.
4. Hard-ball stage (250° to 266°F): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it doesn't flatten until pressed.
5. Soft-crack stage (270° to 290°F): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, but pliable and elastic, threads.
6. Hard-crack stage (295° to 310°F): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, brittle threads that snap easily.

Storing Candies: Most candies will stay fresh for two to three weeks if kept tightly covered in a cool, dry place. Store different types of candies separately. Layer brittles and toffees between sheets of waxed paper in airtight containers. Wrap fudge and fondant in foil or clear plastic wrap and place in airtight containers. Store divinity in airtight containers lined with waxed paper.

tips.title: Bread History and Kneading Tips
notes: American Indians had long been using cornmeal to make their flatbreads by the time the earliest settlers arrived
Plymouth colonists planted wheat and rye seeds brought from Europe; these first crops saved them from starvation
After the Civil War, more bakeries were established producing purer, whiter bread
America's 'wheat belt' from Minnesota and Wisconsin to Iowa and Kansas became the world's greatest producer of grain
Sourdough bread made using an ancient system based on natural 'starter' rather than yeast was brought to America with the first settlers
The invention of the 'sandwich' loaf in 1920 probably revolutionized the American diet

HOW TO KNEAD BREAD: Kneading should be done on a lightly floured surface, a board or counter top; add a little more flour if the dough remains sticky. Knead 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic; it should have tiny air bubbles under the surface.
Turn the dough onto a lightly floured board or counter top. With lightly floured hands, shape the dough into a ball and fold it toward you.
With the heels of hands, using a rolling motion, push it away. Give dough a quarter of a turn.
Knead 8 to 10 minutes; dough should no longer stick and will be ready for second rising or shaping, as recipe directs.

notes: Shellfish types shown: Oysters, Sea and bay scallops, Crawfish, Shrimp (in shells and peeled), Lobster tails, Clams, Mussels, Snow crab legs
Buying: Whether you eat shellfish steamed or boiled, or use them in classic dishes like Crab Mornay or Lobster Newburg, you'll find them irresistible
Shellfish come available live, partially cooked. When buying live shellfish, look for oysters and hard-shell clams that close their shells when you tap them

How to Tell When Seafood Is Cooked: Shellfish can be boiled, broiled, baked, steamed, or fried. When done, shelled oysters, mussels, and clams become plump and opaque; clams and mussels open. Lobsters and crawfish turn bright red. Shrimp turn pink.

tips.title: Fish and Shellfish Tips
notes: FRESHNESS COUNTS: Accept nothing less than the very freshest when buying fish. First, use your nose. Fresh fish in any form has a fresh and mild odor.

For whole, drawn, or dressed fish, look for shiny, taut, and bright skin. The eyes should be clear, bright, and often bulging. The gills should be bright red or pink and not slippery. The skin should be shiny, and the intestinal cavity clean and pink. The flesh should spring back and feel firm and elastic when pressed lightly.
Fillets and steaks should have a moist appearance with clean cuts. Ragged edges and discoloration indicate poor quality.
When buying frozen fish, be sure the flesh is frozen solid. Avoid packages with torn wrappers, or those with frost.

HOW TO STORE: Cook fresh fish as soon as possible, preferably the day you catch it or buy it. If you can't cook it right away, wrap it loosely in clear plastic wrap and refrigerate it up to two days. For longer storage, wrap fresh fish in moisture- and vaporproof wrap and freeze. Frozen fish will keep up to 3 months.
To thaw fish, place the unopened package in the refrigerator for 6 to 8 hours. Do not thaw fish at room temperature or in water because it will thaw unevenly and may spoil. Don't refreeze fish.

To thaw fish in a microwave oven, place 1 pound frozen fillets or steaks in a baking dish. Cover with vented clear plastic wrap. Micro-cook on 30% power (medium-low) for 6 to 8 minutes, turning and separating the fish after 3 minutes. Let fillets stand 10 minutes, and let steaks stand 15 minutes.

tips.title: Pressure Canning Guide
notes: Use a pressure canner to process low-acid foods. Vegetables packed with water, poultry, and meat are low-acid foods that must be processed in a pressure canner.

Make sure all parts work properly and are clean. Check if your canner has a dial gauge; have it checked for accuracy once a year. Contact your county extension service office for the nearest testing location.
Set the steam vent to start canning. Set the check to see that the steam vent is clear by holding it up to light.
SYRUP FOR FRUIT: Choose the syrup that best suits the fruit and your taste. Thinner syrups are for mild-flavored fruits; your taste. The heavier syrups are for tart fruits.

Syrup chart - Type/Sugar/Water/Yield: Very thin (1/2 cup / 4 cups / 4-1/2 cups), Thin (1 cup / 4 cups / 4-3/4 cups), Medium (2 cups / 4 cups / 5 cups), Heavy (3 cups / 4 cups / 5-1/2 cups), Very heavy (4-3/4 cups / 4 cups / 6-1/2 cups)

CANNING AT HIGH ALTITUDES: Times given in this chapter for boiling-water processing are for altitudes less than 1,000 feet above sea level. If you live at a higher altitude, you must use a longer processing time.

For dial-gauge pressure canners, use 11 pounds of pressure if you live up to 2,000 feet above sea level; 12 pounds for 2,001 to 4,000 feet; 13 pounds for 4,001 to 6,000 feet; and 14 pounds for 6,001 to 8,000 feet.
For weighted-gauge pressure canners, use 10 pounds of pressure above sea level. Use 15 pounds of pressure if you live above 1,000 feet.

tips.title: Boiling-Water Canning Guide
notes: BOILING-WATER CANNING: A boiling-water canner is used to process high-acid foods. Use this method for all fruit and tomatoes.

Use a deep kettle, a rack, and a close-fitting lid. Water should be 1 to 2 inches over jar tops. Set the canner and about 2 quarts of water on the range. Fill the jars; adjust lids. Place jars in hot water. Add more water to fill.
DETECTING SPOILAGE: Like commercially canned food, home-canned food will spoil if it isn't properly processed for serving. Check each jar carefully before using.

If mold or has a swollen lid, or the food has patches of mold, a milky appearance, discard the food and the jar. The odor from the opened jar should be pleasant. If the food doesn't look or smell right, destroy it.

NEVER taste food you suspect is spoiled! Those canned foods (those that were improperly processed) can form a toxin in or cause botulism (can cause death). To ensure that the food is safe to eat, bring to a full rolling boil; boil for 10 minutes. If the food is for use at over 1,000 feet above sea level, add one minute for each 1,000 feet of elevation.
LEAVING HEADSPACE: Allowing the proper amount of room between the top of the food and the rim of the container is essential when canning or freezing.
In canning, headspace is necessary for a vacuum to form a good seal. Too little or too much headspace can prevent a good seal.
For wide-top containers and canning jars, leave a 3/4-inch headspace for pints and a 1-1/2-inch headspace for quarts.
For narrow-top containers, leave a 1/2-inch headspace for pints and a 1-inch headspace for quarts.
Unsweetened or dry pack (no sugar or liquid): Leave a 1/2-inch headspace unless directed otherwise.

tips.title: Canning and Freezing Fruits Guide
notes: APPLES: Allow 2-1/2 to 3 pounds per quart. Peel and core; halve, quarter, or slice. Dip into ascorbic-acid color-keeper solution; drain.
APRICOTS: Allow 1-1/2 to 2-1/2 pounds per quart. If desired, peel. Prepare as for peaches.
BERRIES (blackberries, blueberries, currants, elderberries, gooseberries, huckleberries, loganberries, mulberries, raspberries, strawberries): Allow 1-1/2 to 3 pounds per quart.
CHERRIES: Allow 2 to 3 pounds per quart. If desired, pit; prick whole with ascorbic-acid color keeper solution.
MELONS (cantaloupe and watermelon): Allow about 4 pounds per quart.
PEACHES/NECTARINES: Allow 2 to 3 pounds per quart. Peel. Halve and pit. Slice, if desired. Treat with ascorbic-acid color keeper solution; drain.
PEARS: Allow 2 to 3 pounds per quart. Peel; halve and core. Treat with ascorbic-acid color keeper solution; drain.
PLUMS: Allow 1-1/2 to 2-1/2 pounds per quart. Prick skin on 2 sides. Freestone varieties may be halved and pitted.
RHUBARB: Allow 1 to 2 pounds per quart. Discard leaves and woody ends. Cut into 1/2- to 1-inch pieces.
TOMATOES: Allow 2-1/2 to 3-1/2 pounds per quart. Use only unblemished tomatoes. Peel and core. Cut large tomatoes into eighths. Remove seeds, if desired.

tips.title: Canning and Freezing Vegetables Guide
notes: ASPARAGUS: Allow 2-1/2 to 4-1/2 pounds per quart. Wash; scrape off scales. Break off woody bases; wash again. Sort by thickness. Leave whole or cut into 1-inch pieces.
BEANS (green or wax, lima or butter): Allow 1-1/2 to 2-1/2 pounds per quart. Wash; remove ends and strings. Leave whole or snap or cut into 1-inch pieces.
BEETS: Allow 3 to 5 pounds untrimmed per quart. Wash, shell, rinse, drain, and sort beans by size.
BROCCOLI: Allow about 1 pound per pint. Wash; remove outer leaves and tough parts of stalks. Wash again. Cut lengthwise into spears. Cut to fit containers.
CARROTS: Allow 2 to 3 pounds per quart. Rinse; trim, peel, and rinse again. Leave tiny ones whole. For larger ones, slice, dice, or cut into strips.
CAULIFLOWER: Allow 1 to 1-1/2 pounds per pint. Wash; remove leaves and woody stems. Break into 1-inch pieces.
CORN (cream-style): Allow 2 to 3 pounds per pint. Clean as for corn on the cob.
CORN (whole kernel): Allow 4 to 5 pounds per quart. Clean as for corn on the cob.
PEAS (English): Remove husks. Scrub with a vegetable brush to remove silks. Wash and drain.
PEPPERS: Wash. Remove stems, seeds, and membranes. Cut into large pieces or leave whole.
SQUASH (winter and pumpkin): Allow 1-1/2 to 3 pounds per quart. Peel; cut and remove mashed squash or pumpkin.
TURNIPS/RUTABAGAS: Rinse, trim, peel, and rinse again. Slice or cube.

SAFETY REMINDER: Always boil home-canned vegetables (except tomatoes) before tasting or using them. Bring the food to a boil and boil for 10 minutes if you live less than 1,000 feet above sea level. If you live more than 1,000 feet above sea level, add one additional minute for each 1,000 feet of elevation. If you smell an unusual odor as the food heats, discard the food.

tips.title: Jellies and Jams Tips
notes: Jelly making is one canning project you can do year-round. By using either fresh produce or frozen jams, jellies, and products, your family can enjoy your delicious creations for gift giving.
EQUIPMENT: You'll need a large kettle or pot to prevent the mixture from boiling over. To allow for vigorous boiling, the pan should have more than three-fourths of its capacity.

Canning is often done in a boiling-water canner. If you don't have a metal produce basket, before starting, be sure to sterilize the length of the jars by dipping each one in boiling water for at least 15 minutes.
TERMS TO KNOW:
Full Rolling Boil: A boil that is so rapid you can't stir it down with a spoon.

Sheets Off the Spoon: A test for the jelled point. Dip a metal spoon into the boiling mixture, then hold it over the kettle. When two drops come together and fall off together as one sheet, the jelly is ready.

Pectin: A substance in some fruits, especially underripe fruits, that makes the jelly gel or set. Powdered liquid, or sugar mixture that can be used or purchased. Some commercial pectins are added for a recipe if the fruit doesn't have enough natural pectin to gel. Be sure to use the type of pectin called for.

tips.title: Meat Chapter Introduction & Tips
notes: Whether for grilling, braising, roasting, or micro-cooking, the recipes on the following pages bring out the best in beef, veal, pork, and lamb.

RECOGNIZING MEAT CUTS: Our recipes list the most common names for meat cuts. Your butcher, however, may use different names. To be sure you're buying the right cut of meat, refer to the identification pictures in this chapter. Also on these pages, we list the best ways to cook each cut of meat.
HANDLING AND STORING MEAT: Be sure to follow these rules for meat safety:
- Freeze raw meats you don't plan to use in one to two days. Wrap meats in freezer paper or bags.
- Thaw meat overnight in the refrigerator, not at room temperature.
- Thoroughly wash your hands and utensils after handling raw meat.
- Never leave raw or cooked meat at room temperature for more than two hours.

USE THE HOT LINE: Do you have questions about storing and preparing meat? Call the toll-free Meat and Poultry Hotline (800) 535-4555. Home economists from the U.S. Department of Agriculture answer calls from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. eastern time.

tips.title: How to Use a Meat Thermometer
notes: You'll be guaranteed perfect roasts every time if you use a meat thermometer. It's the only accurate way to check doneness.
To be sure you get accurate readings, be sure the thermometer is inserted into the thickest part of the meat without touching fat or bone.
Steps to use a meat thermometer:
1. Push the thermometer into the thickest part of the roast, avoiding fat and bone.
2. The thermometer should register the internal temperature.
3. Continue cooking if the temperature hasn't reached the desired doneness.
4. When the roast reaches 5 to 10 degrees below the desired final temperature, remove it from the oven. The internal temperature will continue to rise as the roast stands.
5. Let roast stand for 15 minutes before carving.

tips.title: Cooking Fish Guide
notes: Fish in most of its forms makes a quick-cooking main dish. Follow the times and directions below, cooking the fish till it flakes easily when tested with a fork.

BAKE: Fresh Fillets or Steaks - Place in single layer in greased shallow baking pan. For fillets, tuck under any thin edges. Brush with melted margarine or butter. Bake uncovered in a 450°F oven for 4 to 6 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness. Frozen - Bake uncovered in a 450°F oven for 9 to 11 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness. Dressed - Bake uncovered in a 350°F oven for 6 to 9 minutes per 1/2 pound.

BROIL: Fresh - Broil 4 inches from the heat for 4 to 6 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness. If fish is 1 inch or more thick, turn it over halfway through broiling. Frozen - Broil 4 inches from the heat for 5 to 9 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness. If fish is 1 inch or more thick, turn it over halfway through broiling. Dressed - Not recommended.

POACH: Add 1½ cups water, broth or wine to a large skillet. Bring to boiling. Add fish. Return to boiling; reduce heat. Simmer, covered for 4 to 6 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness. For frozen steaks, simmer covered for 6 to 9 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness.

GRILL: Place fillets or dressed fish in a well-greased grill basket. Place steaks on a greased grill rack. Grill on an uncovered grill directly over medium-hot coals for 4 to 6 minutes per 1/2-inch thickness, turning once. Brush with melted margarine or butter, if necessary.

MICRO-COOK: For fresh fillets, arrange fish in a single layer in a shallow baking dish. For fillets, tuck under any thin edges. Cover with vented clear plastic wrap. Micro-cook on 100% power (high). For 1/2 pound of 1/2-inch-thick fillets, allow 3 to 4 minutes; for 1 pound of 1/2-inch-thick fillets, allow 4 to 7 minutes. For 1-inch-thick steaks, to 1-inch-thick steaks, allow 7 to 9 minutes.

tips.title: Preparing and Cooking Shellfish Guide
notes: CLAMS: Scrub live clams under cold running water. Combine 4 quarts cold water and 1/3 cup salt. Soak for 15 minutes; rinse. Drain and rinse. Discard water. For 24 clams in shells, add water to an 8-quart Dutch oven to 1/2-inch depth. Bring to boiling; add clams. Steam, covered, for 5 to 8 minutes or till shells open. Discard any that do not open. Serve with melted butter or margarine.

CRAWFISH: Rinse live crawfish under cold running water. For 4 pounds live crawfish, combine 8 quarts cold water and 1/2 cup salt in a 12- to 16-quart kettle. Add crawfish and soak for 15 minutes; rinse, drain. Return 5 quarts water to the kettle; bring to boiling. Reduce heat. Add crawfish. Return to boiling, stirring occasionally. Drain. 5 minutes or till shells turn bright red. Drain. Serve at once with a butter sauce or melted butter or margarine.

LOBSTER TAILS: Thaw frozen tails. For 4 tails in a 3-quart saucepan bring 6 cups water and 1½ teaspoons salt to boiling. Add tails; return to boiling. Reduce heat. Simmer, uncovered, for 8 to 12 minutes for 5-oz tails, 8 to 12 minutes for 6- to 8-oz tails. Drain. Remove meat. Serve with melted butter or margarine.

MUSSELS: Scrub live mussels under cold running water. Using your fingers, pull out the beards that are visible between the shells. Soak (see clams, above). For 24 mussels, add water to an 8-quart Dutch oven to 1/2-inch depth; bring to boiling. Add mussels. Steam, covered, for 3 to 5 minutes or till shells open. Discard any that do not open. Serve with melted butter or margarine.

OYSTERS: Scrub live oysters under cold running water. For easier shucking, chill them before opening. Shuck, reserving bottom shells, if desired. For 24 shucked oysters, simmer uncovered in 2 cups water and 1 teaspoon salt for 1 to 2 minutes or till oysters begin to curl around edges. Drain and chill. Serve on the half shell with a sauce.

SCALLOPS: Thaw shelled scallops, if frozen. Rinse scallops and cut large ones in half. For 1 pound, simmer, uncovered, in 4 cups water and 1 teaspoon salt for 1 to 2 minutes or till opaque. Drain. Use as cooked scallops in a recipe or chill and serve with a sauce.

SHRIMP (in shells or peeled and deveined): Rinse shrimp in shells or peeled shrimp under cold running water and drain. Store in the refrigerator for up to 2 days if not to be used immediately. For 1 pound, simmer, uncovered, in 4 cups water and 1 teaspoon salt for 1 to 3 minutes or till shrimp turn pink, stirring occasionally. Rinse under cold running water. Drain. Use as cooked shrimp in a recipe or chill and serve with a sauce.

Freezing chapter introduction: Enjoy fresh foods all year long by freezing, canning, or pickling them, or by making them into jellies and jams. You'll have foods just the way your family likes them, and always within easy reach.

tips.title: General Freezing Steps Guide
notes: 1. Wash fruits and vegetables with fresh cold water. Prepare as directed on pages 194-195. Follow directions for blanching and cooling.

2. Selecting Containers: Be sure to select varieties of fruits and vegetables recommended for freezing (check seed catalogs), and to freeze the food when it's young, tender, and at its peak of flavor and texture.
3. Put the food in the labeled container (see tip, page 193). For fruit, add sugar or syrup as indicated in the chart on pages 194-195.
4. For fruits, add one of the following packs: Water pack, Sugar pack, or Dry pack. Add no sugar as specified in the chart. Unsweetened pack: Use this for fruit with ascorbic acid color keeper.

5. Wipe any spills from the rims of the containers and jars. Seal containers according to manufacturer's directions, pressing out as much air as possible. If necessary, use freezer tape around the edges of the lids to ensure a tight seal.

Using Frozen Foods: Don't thaw vegetables until ready to cook. These fruits, vegetables, and meats can be cooked or partially thawed (within 8 to 10 months) before using. Leave space between the packages so air can circulate around them.
Wrap solid blocks of food in freezer paper or foil. Fold the edges down in a series of locked folds. Fold in the ends of the package, pressing out air and fitting snugly. Secure with freezer tape.

tips.title: Freezing Prepared Food Guide
notes: BREADS, ROLLS: Bake and cool. Seal in a freezer bag or container. Storage: 3 months. To serve: Thaw in foil in a 300°F oven about 20 minutes.
CAKES, CUPCAKES: Bake, remove from pans, and cool. Freeze on a tray, then wrap. Storage: 6 months. To serve: Thaw, covered, at room temperature 1 to 2 hours.

CASSEROLES: Use less seasoning (some intensify during freezing) and undercook slightly. Cool quickly. Pour into a freezer container. Storage: 2 to 4 weeks. To serve: Bake in a 400°F oven for 1½ hours per quart, baking for first half of time covered.

COOKIES: Unbaked: Drop dough and freeze on a tray. Lift into freezer bags. Baked: Stack with waxed paper, wrap individually. Storage: 6 months. To serve: Bake dropped dough without thawing. Thaw baked cookies at room temperature.
LEFTOVERS (meat with gravy, stews): Cool. Package in rigid freezer containers. Storage: 1 to 3 months. To serve: Thaw, covered, in the refrigerator. Reheat.

PIES: Unbaked: Do not freeze pecan pie. Treat light-colored fruit with ascorbic acid color keeper. Prepare pie as usual but do not cut slits in top crust. Use a metal or freeze-to-oven pie plate. Cover with inverted paper plate to protect crust. Place in a freezer bag. Baked: Do not freeze cream or custard pies. Bake pie and cool. Package as for unbaked pies. Storage: 2 to 4 months. To serve: Unwrap; cut slits in top. Cover edge with foil. Bake frozen pie in a 450°F oven for 15 minutes, then in a 375°F oven for 15 minutes. Uncover; bake about 30 minutes more or till done.

SANDWICHES: Spread bread with margarine. Use cheese, meat, poultry, tuna, salmon, or peanut butter filling. Not recommended: Lettuce, tomatoes, celery, jelly, cooked egg whites, mayonnaise or salad dressing. Storage: 2 months. To serve: Thaw in wrap in the refrigerator for 1 to 2 hours. Thaw other sandwiches at room temperature.

STEWS, SOUPS: Use vegetables that freeze well (not potatoes). Omit salt and thickening. If to be kept longer than 2 months, undercook vegetables. Cool quickly. Pour into freezer containers or bags, leaving some headspace. Storage: 1 to 3 months. To serve: Place frozen food in a heavy saucepan. Cook over low heat, separating often with a fork till hot. Season and thicken.

tips.title: General Canning Steps Guide
notes: CANNING: For year-round enjoyment, follow a canning process suitable food in standard canning jars, topped with lids and screw bands for an airtight seal. Select the freshest, top-quality produce. Sort out any bruised or underripe items.

EQUIPMENT: A water-bath canner is used for processing high-acid foods such as fruits, tomatoes (with added acid), pickles, and relishes. The 212°F temperature produced in the boiling water is sufficient for these foods. A pressure canner is used for processing low-acid foods and vegetables. It reaches temperatures of 240°F to 250°F, the safe level for these foods. This canning method must be followed for safe canning of low-acid foods. A 16-quart pressure canner is ideal.

JARS: Use only standard canning jars, and their mouths are specially designed to seal properly for canning. Run your finger over the mouth of the jars to check for any chips or cracks. Discard any jars with chips or cracks. Use them for dry storage only.

LIDS: Use self-sealing compound bands and flat metal lids with built-in sealing compound. Carefully follow the manufacturer's directions when preparing them. Lids are designed for one-time use, but you can reuse screw bands if they are not bent or rusty.
Foods are packed into canning jars by either raw-pack (cold-pack) or the hot-pack method. In raw packing, the uncooked food is packed into jars.
Other useful pieces of equipment are: a large kettle or Dutch oven, wide-mouth funnel, jar lifter and food mill, colander, or sieve.

STEPS: 1. After the jars are completely cooled, press the center of each lid to check the seal. If it dips up and down, the jar is sealed. If the lid bounces and reprocesses the contents using a clean jar and new lid, processing for the full length of time specified. Or, freeze the food (allowing 1/2-inch headspace). If you plan to use the food within a day or two, you also can refrigerate it.
2. Wipe the jars and lids. Label jars with contents and date. Remove the screw bands. Store in a cool (50° to 70°F), dry, dark place. Use the food within one year.

tips.title: How to Knead Bread
content: Kneading should be done on a lightly floured surface, a board or counter top; add a little more flour if the dough remains sticky.
Knead 8 to 10 minutes until smooth and elastic; it should have tiny air bubbles under the surface.
Turn the dough on to a lightly floured board or counter top. With lightly floured hands, shape the dough into a ball and fold it toward you.
With the heels of hands, using a rolling motion, push it away. Give dough a quarter of a turn.
Knead 8 to 10 minutes; dough should no longer stick and will be ready for second rising or shaping, as recipe directs.
notes: Historical note: American Indians had long been using cornmeal to make their flatbreads by the time the earliest settlers arrived in the New World. The Plymouth colonists planted wheat and rye seeds brought from Europe; these first crops saved them from starvation.

tips.title: Dinner Roll Shapes Guide
content: To make Butterhorns: Lightly grease baking sheets. On a lightly floured surface, roll each half of dough into a 12-inch circle. Brush with melted margarine or butter. Cut each circle into 12 wedges. To shape, begin at wide end of wedge and roll toward point. Place, point side down, 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheets. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 24 rolls.

To make Rosettes: Lightly grease baking sheets. Divide each half of dough into 16 pieces. On a lightly floured surface, roll each piece into a 12-inch rope. Tie in a loose knot, leaving 2 long ends. Tuck top end under roll. Bring bottom end up and tuck into center of roll. Place 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheet. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 32 rolls.

To make Parker House Rolls: Lightly grease baking sheets. On a lightly floured surface, roll each half of dough to ¼-inch thickness. Cut with a floured 2½-inch-round cutter. Brush with melted margarine or butter. Use the dull edge of a table knife to make an off-center crease in each round. Fold each round along the crease so the large half is on top. Press folded edge firmly. (Dough will recede during baking, making the top half shorter than the bottom one.) Place rolls 2 to 3 inches apart on baking sheets. Let rise and bake as directed. Makes 30 rolls.

To make Cloverleaves: Lightly grease 24 muffin cups. Divide each half of dough into 36 pieces. Shape each piece into a ball, pulling edges under to make a smooth top. Place three balls in each greased muffin cup, smooth side up. Let rise; bake as directed. Makes 24.

To make Shortcut Cloverleaves: Lightly grease 24 muffin cups. Divide each half of dough into 12 pieces. Shape each piece into a ball. Place one ball in each muffin cup. With floured scissors, snip top in half, then snip again to make 4 points. Let rise, bake as directed. Makes 24.

tips.title: Steak and Burger Toppings
notes: Mushroom-Onion Sauce: Cook 1 cup sliced fresh mushrooms and ¼ cup sliced green onion in 2 tablespoons margarine or butter. Stir in ½ cup dairy sour cream and ¼ teaspoon pepper. Heat through; do not boil.
Sour Cream and Chive Sauce: Combine ½ cup dairy sour cream, 2 tablespoons snipped chives, 1 tablespoon prepared horseradish, and dash pepper. Chill.

Mustard-Chive Sauce: In a saucepan melt 1 tablespoon margarine or butter. Stir in 2 tablespoons all-purpose flour and ½ teaspoon salt till bubbly. Add ¾ cup milk. Cook and stir till bubbly. Remove from heat. Stir in 1 tablespoon snipped chives and 1 teaspoon Dijon-style mustard.

Parsley Pesto: In a blender container place 2 cups lightly packed chopped parsley, 2 tablespoons chopped walnuts, 1 clove garlic, quartered. Cover and blend till nearly smooth. Stir in ¼ cup grated Parmesan cheese.

tips.title: Kitchen Tip: Judging Ground Meat Doneness
content: For safety's sake, we recommend cooking all meat loaves and meatloaf-type ground-meat patties to 170° or till no pink remains.
Ground-meat patties, with no other ingredients added, however, may be cooked till their centers are brownish pink (medium doneness).

tips.title: Kitchen Tip: Candy Temperature Stages
content: Thread stage (230° to 233°): When a teaspoon is dipped into the hot mixture, then removed, the candy falls off the spoon in a fine, thin thread.
Soft-ball stage (234° to 240°): When the ball of candy is removed from the cold water, the candy instantly flattens and runs between your fingers.
Firm-ball stage (244° to 248°): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it is firm enough to hold its shape, but quickly flattens at room temperature.
Hard-ball stage (250° to 266°): When the ball of candy is removed from the water, it doesn't flatten until pressed.
Soft-crack stage (270° to 290°): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, but pliable and elastic, threads.
Hard-crack stage (295° to 310°): When dropped into water, the candy separates into hard, brittle threads that snap easily.
notes: Always use a candy thermometer for best results
The water test is a backup method if you don't own a candy thermometer
